moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3: I don't normally like playing 3 knights or the 4 knights opening but didn't see anything better at the time.
moves.3... Nc6 4. Bb5: Transposing into my favorite: the Ruy Lopez.
moves.4... Bb4 5. O-O O-O: It was at this point that I realized that he was copying me move for move. Now all I had to figure out was how to break the copycat moves and checkmate him...
moves.6. Ne2 a6: Ok, so I didn't expect that...no problem though. Also, I don't normally leave the e-pawn exposed but I was thinking of moving my pawn to c3.
moves.7. Ba4 Ne7 8. c3 Bc5 9. d4 exd4 10. Nexd: There goes my e-pawn. Definitely not what I had hoped for.
moves.11. Bc2: My idea here was to set up for the classic bishop sacrifice. I was sure that he would move to Nf6 and block that play completely but...
moves.11... d6: A blunder on his part by losing his knight. I think he was trying to pin my knight.
moves.12. Bxe4 Bg4: voila! Now back to my bishop sacrifice. I was pretty sure that I wouldn't get a mate from this position but I thought I could at best get material and at least mess up his kingside pawn structure. Either way, I was ahead in material so it couldn't hurt.
moves.13. Bxh7+ Kxh7 14. Ng5+ Kg8 15. Qxg4: Reclaiming the bishop that I had sacrificed and also getting the h7 pawn.
moves.15... Re8 16. Qh5 Ng6: The only real play he had.
moves.18... Ke7: The fatal blunder as he waves goodbye to his queen.
